div1.p: Cassidy's article briefly tells the story of the yellow fever experiments, the discovery by Hench of the correct location of Camp Lazear, and the eventual dedication of the site.

div1.head: Story by Helen Cassidy, [April, 1953]
div1.p:
An interest in medical history sounds like a scholarly and
passive pursuit: reading large and dusty volumes, visiting museums,
viewing monuments inscribed “On this spot.........”

But sometimes even a spare time medical historian plays a much
more active role.

Take Dr. Philip S. Hench. Last December, in Marianao, Cuba
he participated in the dedication of a memorial to the group of men
whose work contributed to the eradication of yellow fever. The

The Camp Lazear National Monument is located on the site
where a commission of the U. S. National Board of Health, headed
by Walter Reed, carried out work which proved the theory of the
Cuban scientist, Dr. Carlos Finlay, that yellow fever is transmitted
by the mosquito.

And it was Dr. Hench, who, by long-time study and sharp-eyed
observation, was able to correctly identify the location of Camp Lazear.
It happened this way.

Back in 1940 Dr. Hench made a trip to Havana, Cuba. He
wanted to see -- if they still existed -- the two wooden shacks where
the mosquito theory had been proved. He wanted to meet the son and
daughter of two of the men who had particpated in the work, to learn
from them some not-in-the-history-books details of the story. He
wanted to meet Johnny Moran, an American soldier who had volunteered
to be biten by a “loaded” mosquito and developed one of the first
cases of “deliberately accepted and completely controlled experimental
yellow fever.”

The story of the conquering of yellow fever is a dramatic one.
Briefly it is this.
Hench-2-

In the latter part of the 1800's, incidence of yellow
fever reached plague proportions in Cuba. During the Spanish American
War it accounted for a major portion of the deaths among American
soldiers. In 1900

In 1900 there was created the United States Army Special
Yellow Fever Board, to work in Cuba, whose members included Major
Walter Reed, Drs. James Carroll, Aristides Agramonte and Jesse
Lazear.

These men examined the existing theories of the cause of yellow
fever -- that it came from a miasma that rose over tropical swamps;
that it was due to a germ which an Italian physician believed he had
discovered; that it was transmitted from the infected clothing and
belongings of its victims. Finally, there was the theory of a Havana
physician, Dr. Carlos Finlay, that yellow fever was transmitted by
the common house mosquito, which sucked in the infection with the
blood of a fever victim, then passed it on to persons it might later bite.

Lazear began to breed Finlay's mosquitos in the camp
laboratory. Ten American soldiers -- including Drs. Lazear and Carroll --
allowed themselves to be bitten by presumably infected mosquitos. Nothing
happened. But then Dr. Carroll was re-innoculated. In a few days
he developed a severe and almost fatal attack of yellow fever. A scoffing
volunteer soldier who “wasn't afraid of any little old gnat,” died
following an infected mosquito's bite.

Lazear, who happily wrote his wife, “I rather think I am
on the right track,” a few days later fell ill and died of yellow fever.
At the time his death was listed as due to “accidental yellow fever.”
Later indications were that the disease resulted from again exposing himself secretly
to the bite of infected mosquitos.

There were now -- counting Lazear -- three cases of mosquito-induced
yellow fever. To carry out more completely controlled experiments,
Hench-3-
to gather irrefutable evidence for their theory, Reed, Carroll and
Agramonte set up an experimental camp, which, to honor their dead
colleague, they named Camp Lazear.

Two small buildings were erected. In one, the “infected
clothing and bedding building,” volunteers were exposed to clothing and
bedding used by a yellow fever victims. None of them developed
yellow fever.

The second building, the “infected mosquito building,” was
divided into two parts by a wire screen. In one portion infected
mosquitos were present; in the other, no mosquitos. There fourteen
American and Spanish volunteers -- among them Johnny Moran -- allowed
themselves to be bitten by mosquitos. They all developed yellow
fever. Men on the other side of the screen, where there were no
mosquitos, remained well.

This was accepted as conclusive evidence that yellow fever
was transmitted by the mosquito. With this knowledge, General
William Gorgas, U. S. Army sanitation expert, within three months
freed Havana of yellow fever. The same knowledge later made it
possible to complete the Panama Canal.

This was the story which had long intrigued the imagination
of Dr. Hench, which in 1940 led him to Cuba on a “sentimental journey.”

Johnny Moran met him there, took him to a small enclosed
plot of ground. A large sign stated: “On this spot was established
‘El Campamento Lazear’.......”

Dr. Hench, who had read every publication of Walter Reed
he could get his hands on, couldn't reconcile location of the plot
(bordering a spur railroad track which led to a bathing beach) with
the “secluded spot” described in the Reed papers.

Back at his hotel that night he read again the papers of Reed.
Hench-4-
There he found a statement that the camp had been located “on the
farm of Dr. Ignacio Rojas.”

A real estate man helped him identify the Rojas farm.
Its present occupant, an elderly woman, admitted that “Yes, there
were American soldiers with a few tents and a couple of buildings
erected on the rear of this farm.”

When asked to take them to their location she hesitated, then
spoke in Spanish to a servant. Johnny Moran, grinning, translated
for Dr. Hench: “She isn't taking any chances with you. She told
her servant she is going into our car with us to another part of the
farm, but if she doesn't return in half an hour please come after
her. She is afraid you might kidnap her.”

Moran and Dr. Hench located a shack which, though in the
right location didn't appear the right shape of the Camp Lazear
buildings. But a curious and friendly Cuban told them, “Yes, the
American soldiers lived in this building and got yellow fever. My
father told me that.”

It is this building, completely reconstructed and divested
of the lean-tos that obscured its identiy, which is the center of
the present Camp Lazear National Monument. There are bronze medallions
honoring the scientists who contributed to the work, the American and
Cuban soldiers who voluntarily exposed themselves to yellow fever,
and “all who cooperated.”

There, on the day of dedication, Dr. Hench, representing
the Mayo Foundation, placed a wreath honoring Drs. Finlay, Reed and
their associates. There were many more wreaths, from universities,
medical societies, the Surgeon General of the United States.
Hench-5-

Dr. Hench, and others, in see in the memorial more than a
record of a great medical achievement. In concluding his address
delivered at the dedication ceremonies Dr. Hench stated:

“Of the 25 principal men whose hopes were fulfilled at
Camp Lazear, three were Cubans, four were Spainards, one was English,
one was Irish and 16 were Americans. Some were humbly born; some
reached high estate; some were civilians, others were soldiers,
professionals and volunteers; some were Catholic, some were
Protestant, some were Hebrews. And here on this hemisphere's 23rd
parallel they demonstrated well the potential brotherhood of man.”
